Typography

Major Titles - H1

H1 is reserved for the top level of information. There should only be one h1 on a page at a time. Example use: the name of our application.

Subtitles - H2

H2 is the next tier of information below the singular H1. Example use: Area titles within an application.

Section Titles - H3

h3 is a great candidate for sections and blocks

Subsection titles - H4

Minor emphasis divider - H5
Supplemental information - H6

Paragraph - Remember your hierarchy. Paragraph tags tend to share type styles with other body text, like lists, inside section tags, aside tags, captions, modals etc.

Lists


.standard-list {
  @extend %list--default;
}
.standard-numbered-list{
  @extend %list--ordered;
}
.horizontal--list {
  @extend %list--horizontal;
  li {
    padding-right: 10px;
    &:last-child {
      padding-right:0;
    }
  }
}

Quiver is geared for web applications. In applications we use unordered lists (ul) often, but not in their typical default browser presentation.

Our default base removes some browser assumptions about ULs.

  • Luke
  • Leia
  • Han

We have added a placeholder which can reinstate the default UL style if needed.

%list--default

Results in a list like this:

  • Mal
  • Jayne
  • Kaylee

Likewise, here is the placeholder for a standard ordered list (ol).

%list--ordered
  1. Dwarf Fortress
  2. Minecraft
  3. FTL

Horizontal List: @extend %list--horizontal

  • Mal
  • Jayne
  • Kaylee
